Fig. 1 (a) Schematic illustration for the preparation of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re samples; XRD patterns of (b) MgxAl−LDHs, (c) RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs, (d) Ru/MgxAl−LDOs and (e) Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images and corresponding particle size distribution of Ru nanoparticles of (a) Ru/Mg1Al−LDH−Re, (b) Ru/Mg2Al−LDH−Re, (c) Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re and (d) Ru/Mg4Al−LDH−Re. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Effect of Mg/Al molar ratio (a), reaction temperature (b) and light intensity (c) on the hydrogen production rate in methanol APR. (d) Kinetic isotope effects (KIE) over Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re. (e) Catalytic stability of Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re. (f) Apparent activation energy for the methanol APR over Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re catalyst for thermal reaction and light reaction. Reaction conditions: 50 mg catalyst; 2 mL methanol, 18 mL H2O, Ar, 2 atm. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms, (b) The corresponding pore size distribution curves, (c) CO2–TPD results and (d) H2–TPR of various samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) High resolution XPS spectrum of Ru 3p; (b) High resolution XPS spectrum of O 1 s; (c) PL spectra and (d) EPR spectra of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re catalyst; (e) The UV-Vis DRS of MgxAl−LDHs support and Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re catalysts; (f) The output spectrum of high pressure mercury lamp. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Time dependent in situ DRIFTS of APR of methanol over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re catalyst performed in the dark (a) and under light irradiation (b) at 150 °C. Time dependent in situ DRIFTS of WGS over Ru/Al2O3 (c) and Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re (d) catalyst in the dark at 150 °C. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) Oxygen vacancy model: Ru4/ov-LDH; (b) Perfect model: Ru4/per-LDH. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) Bader charge of Ru4 cluster; (b) PDOS of the Ru 4d states on various substrates. The blue dashed line indicates the mean d-band center (εd) of the Ru4 cluster, and the vertical blue line indicates the Fermi energy at 0 eV. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The reaction path of methanol and water for hydrogen production. (a) Energy profiles for CH3OH dissociation on ov-LDH and per-LDH surfaces. The x axis shows the reaction intermediates and transition states (TSs); the y axis shows the relative energy of each state. (b) Energy profiles for CO2 formation via the water–gas shift reaction on these two surfaces. H, O, Mg, Al, Ru, and C atoms are shown in white, red, green, purple, cyan, and grey, respectively, a subscript ‘g’ denotes a gas-phase reactant or product. State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 China Catalytic aqueous phase reforming of methanol is a promising process for the sustainable hydrogen production. The search for highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst is a topic of interest. Herein, we report oxygen vacancies enriched MgAl−LDHs supported plasmonic Ru nanoparticles catalyst exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance for efficient hydrogen production at 150 ºC under light irradiation. Characterizations demonstrate abundant oxygen vacancies are introduced into MgAl−LDHs via “memory effect”. The local electron transfer from oxygen vacancies of the MgAl−LDHs to the Ru nanoparticles leading the formation of electron-rich Ru species, which promote the dehydrogenation of methanol under light irradiation. In situ DRIFTS demonstrated a redox mechanism of water-gas shift reaction due to the existence of oxygen vacancies, which resulted a faster hydrogen production rate. This work displays a facile strategy for synthesis of oxygen vacancies rich LDH supported metal nanoparticles catalysts and deep understanding into the pathway and mechanism toward the effective hydrogen production. Graphical Abstract Oxygen vacancies enriched MgAl−LDH supported plasmonic Ru nanoparticle photocatalysts exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance in aqueous phase reforming of methanol, owing to the synergism of light irradiation promoted dehydrogenation of methanol and oxygen vacancy promoted water−gas shift reaction via redox mechanism. Keywords Hydrogen production Aqueous phase reforming Oxygen vacancy Ru nanoparticle Light irradiation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen represent a promising potential source of clean energy due to its high energy density and zero carbon emission [1]. For example, hydrogen used in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) can convert the chemical energy into electrical energy efficiently [2,3]. However, hydrogen is a kind of secondary energy sources, H atoms exist in the form of combination with other elements like H2O, CH4, CH3OH and other compounds. The effective H2 production is of great importance for its large-scale application. Ever since the pioneering work developed by Dumesic et al., aqueous phase reforming of oxygenated hydrocarbons is regarded as one of the most promising routes for sustainable hydrogen production [4,5]. Among which, methanol is the ideal raw-material for APR due to its high H2 gravimetric density, low price and mass manufacturing. Zhang et. al reported that hydrogen production using methanol as raw materials has been considered as an alternative strategy towards conventional methane stream reforming owing to its milder reaction condition and lower carbon footprint.[6,7] However, the state-of-the-art catalyst for the production of hydrogen from renewable sources is still conducted at high temperatures ( > 200 °C) and high pressures (25–50 bar), which greatly limits its potential applications [8–10]. A deep understanding of the mechanism of methanol APR is the prerequisite for new catalyst design. As reported in the literatures, the methanol APR reaction including separated kinetically relevant steps: namely methanol dehydrogenation and followed by water−gas shift reaction (WGS) [11]. Therefore, both methanol and water need to be activated effectively to achieve high H2 production rate. This enlightens us that the designed catalyst should contain at least two separated active sites for methanol and water activation. Traditionally, Pt, Pd, Ru, Cu and Ni based metal catalyst have been widely used in the APR process due to their high methanol dehydrogenation ability [12–16]. Supported Ru metal have been proved to be an active catalyst in the reported literatures [17–19]. On the other hand, the catalyst support is another important factor that affect the catalytic activity. For example, Lin et al. reported α-MoC support single Pt atom catalysts for methanol APR reaction, they attributed the high catalytic performance to the outstanding ability of α-MoC to induce water dissociation [20]. Wang et al. also found the oxygen vacancy-rich NiAl2O4 supported Pt nanoparticles catalyst exhibited much higher catalytic performance in methanol APR reaction than that of conventional Pt/Al2O3 catalyst, which is due to the effective H2O activation over the oxygen vacancy sites for the faster WGS reaction [11,21]. As widely reported, the oxygen vacancy of reducible support like FeOx, CeO2-x and TiO2-x can act as active site for H2O activation in the WGS reaction, which lead the WGS experiences a faster redox mechanism other than the associative route occur over the support without oxygen vacancy [22–25]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), a class of highly ordered two-dimensional anionic clays, are made up of positively charged layers (+2 and +3) and charge balancing anions. We have previously successfully introduced oxygen vacancy into LDHs via “memory effect”, the LDHs calcined at a certain temperature could reconstruct the original order layered structure through hydration process [26–28]. Thus, taking the advantage of adjustable structure of LDHs, we choose MgAl-LDHs as the catalyst carrier. As is reported recently, the catalytic performance of supported Ru nanoparticles catalyst can be effectively promoted via a photoexcited process, due to localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect under visible light irradiation [29]. Therefore, it is very attractive to drive the methanol APR reaction with solar energy at low temperature in view of the gradual depletion of fossil resources. This also offers a possibility that the catalytic activity of methanol APR reaction can also be promoted by the LSPR effect of Ru. Consequently, in this work, oxygen vacancy enriched MgAl−LDH supported Ru nanoparticle catalyst was prepared via impregnation-reduction method and rehydration process, which exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the methanol APR reaction. The high H2 production rate was due to that the promoted dehydrogenation of methanol over Ru sites under light irradiation and the enhanced WGS reaction over the oxygen vacancy sites. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Al(NO3)3•9 H2O, Mg(NO3)2•6 H2O and urea are purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). RuCl3⋅xH2O (37.5–41.0 wt% Ru) and HPLC-grade methanol were purchased from Adamas (Shanghai, China). CD3OD was purchased from Energy Chemical. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Ultrapure water was used in all experimental processes. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of MgxAl−LDHs The MgxAl−LDHs with various Mg/Al molar ratio was synthesized according to previous reported method. Typically, 4.0 g of Al(NO3)3•9 H2O, 8.2 g of Mg(NO3)2•6 H2O, 5 g of urea and 250 mL ultrapure water were added into a 500 mL round bottom flask. After stirred at 92 °C in an oil bath for 24 h, the sample was carefully washed with ultrapure water to neutral, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 110 °C overnight to obtain MgxAl−LDHs. 2.2.2 Preparation of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re 2 g of MgAl−LDHs was dispersed in 200 mL ultrapure water, then 12.56 g RuCl3⋅xH2O solution (0.012 mol L−1) was added and stirred for 3 h, and dried at 120 °C overnight, the obtained powder was denoted as RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs, the designed Ru content is 6 wt%. Then the sample was reduced in a 5 % H2/Ar at 550 °C for 8 h with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1, the resulted sample was denoted as Ru/MgxAl−LDOs. Then placed in 100 mL sodium hydroxide solution (2.6 mM) and stirred at 60 °C for 4 h, followed by filtration, washing thoroughly with ultrapure water. Finally, the sample was dried at 120 °C overnight to obtain Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re. Other catalysts with different Ru contents were prepare via the same method except that different amount of RuCl3⋅xH2O solution was added. 2.2.3 Preparation of Ru/Al2O3 Ru/Al2O3 was prepared as following: 2 g of Al2O3 was dispersed in 200 mL ultrapure water, then 12.56 g RuCl3⋅xH2O was added and stirred for 3 h, followed by filtration, washing thoroughly with ultrapure water, and dried at 120 °C overnight, then the sample was reduced in a 5 % H2/Ar at 550 °C for 8 h with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1, the resulted sample was denoted as Ru/Al2O3. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the catalysts were obtained by a JEM 2010 microscope with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image to characterize the surface morphologies of the as-prepared MgxAl−LDHs sample was performed on a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FESEM, JSM 7001-F, JEOL, Japan). The nitrogen sorption isotherms were measured on a Tristar II 3020 volumetric adsorption analyzer. Prior to measurement, 0.2 g of the sample was degassed at 120 °C for 12 h under vacuum. The surface area was calculated from the adsorption branch in the relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.25 by the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) method and the pore size distribution was derived from the adsorption branch by Barrett−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) method, the pore volume was estimated at a relative pressure of 0.99. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on a Rigaku MiniFlex II desktop X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation source. The measurement was conducted in the 2θ range from 5° to 80° at a scanning rate of 4° min−1. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor II spectrometer, 1 mg of catalyst sample was pressed into a pellet with 100 mg of KBr then measured in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. The contents of Mg, Al and Ru were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) with a Thermo iCAP6300 spectrometer. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 instrument, with an Al Kα monochromator X-rays source. The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-Vis DRS) were observed on a Hitachi U-3900 spectrometer in the range of 200–800 nm. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were measured using a Bruker EMXPLUS EPR electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer at −196 °C operating at 100.00 kHz. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were conducted on Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer (excitation wavelength at 320 nm). CO2-temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) was conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer. The catalyst sample was first pretreated under an argon flow (30 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 60 min, and then cooling down to 50 °C. After that, a flow of CO2 (30 mL min−1) was switched into the system. And the catalyst sample was purged with Ar again for 60 min and heated up to 800 °C at a ramp of 10 °C min−1. The amount of CO2 uptake during the heating for reduction was measured by a thermal conductivity detector. H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out with a heating ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 in 10 % H2/Ar mixture to 700 °C, with a total flow rate of 40 mL min−1. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out in an N2 atmosphere from 30 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 with a Rigaku Thermo plus Evo TG 8120 analyzer. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) of the methanol APR on the catalysts was performed on Bruker Tensor II IR spectrometer equipped with MCT detector and a Praying Mantis™ HVC accessory enclosed with three-window dome. Prior to the measurement, the sample was loaded in the cell and treated in situ at 120 °C in argon flow (50 mL min−1) to eliminate surface impurities. The background spectrum was collected after the system cooled to room temperature·H2O or CH3OH or reactant mixture (H2O+CH3OH) was then introduced by bubbling argon (50 mL min−1) through a saturator kept at 25 °C. A series of DRIFTS were then collected repeatedly at room temperature every 4 minutes until the signal become stable. For the in situ reaction of H2O and CH3OH on the catalyst surface, the in situ cell was under a Xenon lamp irradiation for 1 minute before the spectrum was collected. In situ DRIFTS of WGS: The samples were in situ pretreated at 300 °C for 4 h in a flow of 10 % H2/Ar, and a flow of Ar for another 0.5 h. Then, the sample was cooled down to 150 °C. Subsequently, the mixture of CO and H2O was introduced into the reaction cell via 1 % CO/Ar bubbling with 50 mL min−1. Then the DRIFTS were recorded every 4 minutes. 2.4 Catalyst tests and analytic procedures The catalytic performance activity was evaluated in a 100 mL stainless-steel Teflon-lined autoclave with an automatic temperature control system and quartz window. Besides, an air conditioner was set and attached to the light-reaction chamber to control the reaction temperature carefully. The illumination area is 5 cm−2. typically, 50 mg of catalyst, 2 mL CH3OH and 18 mL H2O were loaded into the autoclave, purged with argon for 3 times and charged at 2 atm. Then the reactor was heated to the desired reaction temperature under a 500 W high pressure mercury lamp irradiation, and stirred for 4 h. The reaction time was started to countdown when the reaction temperature raised to the setting value, after a reaction time of 4 h, the gas product mixture was analyzed by Shimadzu GC-2014 C immediately. The gas products were analyzed by a gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014 C), H2 was analyzed by TCD detector and 5 A molecular sieve packed column; CO, CH4 and CO2 were analyzed by FID detector and TDX-1 packed column. The isotopic labeling experiments for methanol aqueous reforming reaction were measured using CD3OD at 150 °C. The kinetic isotope effect (KIE) was calculated based on the reaction rates with CH3OH and CD3OD reactants. 2.5 Computational details The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the periodic supercell approach via the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [30,31]. The projector augmented wave method (PAW) was used for electron-ion interactions [32]. Electronic structures of bulk were calculated using the Perdew−Burke−Ernzerhof (PBE) form of the generalized gradient approximation expanded in a plane wave basis [33]. All calculations involved spin polarization. The kinetic energy cutoff plane-wave expansion was set to 400 eV. The total energy convergence for structural optimization was set to less than 10−5 eV, and the force convergence was set to less than 0.03 eV/Å. The Brillouin zone was sampled using a 3×3×1 Monkhorst-Pack grid [34]. The climbing image general nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was used to locate the transition states (TSs) [35]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Samples preparation and structural characterization Ru nanoparticle catalyst supported on rehydrated LDHs with various Mg/Al ratios (Ru/MgxAl−LDHs, x=1, 2, 3, 4) were prepared as following: RuCl3 was first loaded on MgxAl−LDHs precursors via a wet impregnation method, then reduced in a 5 % H2/Ar flow and finally a rehydration process ( Fig. 1a). MgxAl−LDHs precursors were prepared by a urea hydrolysis method following established procedures with some modification. The XRD patterns of MgxAl−LDHs precursors shown in Fig. 1b exhibited characteristic peaks at 12.0°, 23.9°, 35.2°, 39.8° and 47.5°, corresponding to (003), (006), (012), (015) and (018) planes, respectively. The counter anions in the interlayer region are mainly CO3 2- groups. The SEM image in Fig. S1 shows a typical hexagon-nanosheet morphology with a diameter of ∼3.5 μm and a thickness of 0.05−0.1 μm. The MgxAl−LDHs loaded RuCl3 samples (RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs) show no variation in the XRD patterns (Fig. 1c) compared with MgxAl−LDHs, suggesting the structure of MgxAl−LDHs was not affected after loading of RuCl3. To determine the thermal reduction temperature for RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs, the TG curves were firstly investigated. All the four samples exhibited similar decomposition behavior (Fig. S2). Three weight loss steps including the dehydration of interlayer water, the dehydroxylation of OH bound with Al, the dehydroxylation of OH bound with Mg and the main CO2 evolution were observed for all MgxAl−LDH samples. It is concluded that the structure of MgxAl−LDHs can transform to stable MgxAl-layered double oxides (MgxAl−LDOs) when calcinated at 550 °C, thus we choose the 550 °C as the optimum calcination temperature for all samples. It is worth to note that the sample with Mg/Al=3:1 shows the largest weight loss compared with other samples, which may introduce much more defects sites into the framework of MgxAl-LDHs. As shown in Fig. 1d, after thermal reduction of RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs in H2/Ar at 550 °C, the structure of MgxAl−LDHs transformed to MgxAl−LDOs. The XRD patterns show a predominant MgO-periclase phase (36.7°, 43.8°, and 63.6°). None signal of Ru can be observed, suggesting the Ru species are highly dispersed or in small size. After rehydration process of the Ru/MgxAl−LDOs, the topology structures of MgxAl−LDHs were recovered via “memory effect” and finally the Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re catalysts were obtained. As shown in Fig. 1e, the XRD patterns of the rehydrated MgxAl-LDH show characteristic (003), (006), (012), (015), and (018) reflections at characteristic peaks of 11.6°, 23.3°, 34.8°, 39.3° and 46.9°, respectively. The characteristic Bragg diffraction peak of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re shift to the low 2 θ degree compared with that of MgxAl−LDHs precursors, this may be due to a replacement of CO3 2− by OH− groups in the interlayer region. Correspondingly, the interlayer space increased after the rehydration process. Besides, the peak intensity of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re become broader and weaker compared with that of the original MgxAl−LDHs precursors, indicating that the crystal size of the Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re nanosheets become smaller and an increase of degree of disorder, a large amount of defects sites like oxygen vacancies may be introduced into the framework of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re during the topological transformation process[36]. The low-magnification TEM images of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re in Fig. 2a1-d1 show typical hexagonal platelet particle shape with a diameter of 3.0 ± 0.3 μm, which is consistent with the SEM result. Abundant Ru nanoparticles are highly dispersed on the surface of MgxAl−LDHs−Re (Fig. 2a2-d2) with a similar average particle size of 1.7−1.9 nm (Fig. 2a3-d3). The Ru content of Ru/MgxAl−LDH−Re samples determined by ICP were close to the designed value of 5 wt% in Table S1. 3.2 Photocatalytic H2 production from methanol aqueous-phase reforming The photocatalytic performance of the as synthesized Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re in the hydrogen production from methanol aqueous-phase reforming reaction were evaluated. The reaction was conducted in a stainless-steel batch reactor with quartz window and a high-pressure mercury lamp as light source. As shown in Fig. S3, the hydrogen production rates increased with the increase of Ru content from 2 wt%, 4 wt% and 6 wt%. However, the increase of hydrogen production rate was very slow when further increase the Ru content to 8 wt%, thus we chose the Ru content of 6 wt% as the optimum value. A volcano-like reactivity trends of hydrogen production rate with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio was experimentally observed in Fig. 3a. The highest hydrogen production rate of 118.9 μ mol g−1 min−1 was obtained over the Ru/MgxAl−LDH−Re catalyst with a Mg/Al molar ratio of 3, suggesting the Mg/Al molar ratio have a great influence on the catalytic activity. As shown in Table S2, the catalytic performance of Ru/MgxAl−LDH−Re exhibited a H2 production rate of 421.8 μ mol g−1 min−1 at 190 °C with the assistance of light irradiation, which is much higher than that reported in literatures. The hydrogen production rate was much higher under light irradiation than that in the dark for all four Ru/MgxAl−LDH−Re catalysts with various Mg/Al molar ratio, indicating that light can effectively promote the reaction. The effect of reaction temperatures on the catalytic performance was investigated (Fig. 3b). The light contribution to the hydrogen production rate was calculated by subtracting the hydrogen production rate in the dark from the overall hydrogen production rate under light irradiation with the same reaction temperature. The hydrogen production rate obtained without light irradiation is considered as the thermal contribution. The hydrogen production rates increase with the elevated temperature both in the dark and under light irradiation. However, the contribution of light irradiation decreased from 66.7 % to 23.6 % with the increase of reaction temperature from 150 to 190 °C. This is due to that the amounts of thermal-activated energetic electrons at high temperature are sufficient to surmount the activation barrier and trigger the reaction. That is to say, the required amounts of LSPR induced energetic electrons become less, which resulted in a decrease of the contribution of light irradiation. The effect of light intensity on the hydrogen production rate was investigated at 150 °C (Fig. 3c). With the increase of light intensity from 0.00 to 0.05, 0.1 and 0.15 W cm–2, the hydrogen production rate increased from 39.6 to 46.4, 62.9 and 118.9 μ mol g–1 min–1, respectively. The numbers with percentages show the light irradiation contribution. The larger the contribution of irradiation to the overall hydrogen production rate was obtained at the higher light intensity. The light contribution increased from 0 % to 14.7 %, 37.1 % and 66.7 %, respectively. When the irradiance is 0.05 W cm–2, the light contribution is only 14.7 %, and when the irradiance increased to 0.15 W cm–2, the light contribution to hydrogen production rate increased to 66.7 %. This is because a greater light intensity means the Ru nanoparticles can give more light induced “hot electrons” to take part in the methanol APR reaction, which is an experimental feature of charge-carrier driven reactions. To further demonstrate the methanol APR reaction is indeed driven by LSPR induced hot carries, the kinetic isotope effect (KIE) experiment was conducted (Fig. 3d). It is well established that an elevated KIE value compared with the KIE related to the phonon-driven chemical reactions (thermal reaction) is an important feature of plasmon-driven chemical process on metal NPs surface. The KIE value of Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re catalyst is 3.09 under light irradiation, which is much larger than the KIE in the dark (2.28), suggesting the boosting hydrogen production rate was attributed to the plasmon induced “hot electrons” on the surface of Ru nanoparticles under light irradiation. No significant decrease of catalytic activity of Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re catalyst was discovered after the catalyst reused 6 times (Fig. 3e), demonstrating the excellent stability under the optimized reaction conditions. The kinetics of the methanol APR reaction over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re catalyst were then examined. The apparent Ea for Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re under light irradiation is 62.5 kJ mol−1 calculated from the slope of the Arrhenius plot (Fig. 3f), which is reduced by around 25 % compared to that in the dark (84.2 kJ mol−1). This indicates that light irradiation significantly improved the catalytic activity. To discover ultraviolet or visible light mainly functioned in this photocatalytic reaction. We investigated the effect of irradiation wavelength on the hydrogen production rate in the APRM reaction. As shown in Table S3, we believe the ultraviolet light was the main force for the photocatalysis. 3.3 Probing the origin of high photocatalytic performance Control experiments were further performed to understand the intrinsic active sites of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re in the hydrogen production from APR of methanol. The hydrogen cannot be detected when using the MgxAl−LDHs support under the optimum reaction conditions (Table S4, entries 1–4), indicating that the Ru nanoparticles are the main active centers. The RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs sample exhibited poor catalytic performance in the APR of methanol (Table S4, entries 5–8), further suggested that the coordinated Ru species over MgxAl−LDHs support contribute little catalytic activity to the hydrogen production, even though it showed excellent catalytic activity in the reduction of carbonyl compounds via blue light irradiation in our previous report [37]. A series of characterizations were conducted to explore the origin of the excellent catalytic performance of Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re catalyst. The BET surface areas for the Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re catalysts were calculated to be 125.3, 105.4, 76.4 and 73.1 m2 g–1, respectively (Table S1), indicating that the influence of specific surface area on the catalytic performance is negligible because the worst catalyst Ru/Mg1Al−LDHs−Re possess the largest specific surface area. The Fig. 4a show nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of typical IV with a hysteresis loop according to the IUPAC classification, indicating a mesoporous structure for all samples. The pore size distribution curves in Fig. 4b deduced from desorption branches of the nitrogen sorption isotherms suggest that Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re catalysts are made up of pores with average sizes of 13.9, 12.1, 11.3 and 11.8 nm, respectively. Those results show that although the Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re samples with various Mg/Al molar ratio possess similar pore structure, the specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of the Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re samples gradually decrease with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio. The surface acidity or basicity of catalyst support is of great importance, because catalyst support with acidic sites often leads the formation of undesired alkanes in APR reaction. It is well established that surface basicity of supported metal nanoparticles catalyst is benefit for hydrogen production from APR of biomass-derived hydrocarbons. Zhang et al. found that the catalytic activity increased with the increase of support base strength on Ni-based catalysts because the basic sites are beneficial to water–gas shift reaction [38]. The surface basicity of the recovered MgxAl−LDHs supported Ru nanoparticles catalysts has been determined by CO2-TPD technique. As shown in Fig. 4c, the CO2 desorption peak at around 85 °C was belong the weak basic sites, and the desorption peak located at between 220 and 500 °C can be assigned to the medium and strong basic sites. As reported in the literatures [39], the weak, medium and strong basic sites are derived from OH−, metal–oxygen pair (Mg2+–O2− and Al3+–O2−) and low coordination oxygen anion (O2 −), respectively. The CO2 desorption peaks shift to higher temperature with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio, suggesting that the Mg/Al molar ratio can regulation the surface basicity effectively. The concentrations of base sites of various Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re samples are given in Table S5. Notably, the catalyst Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re has the largest amount of both weak basic sites (0.184 mmol g−1), medium (1.590 mmol g−1) and strong acidic sites (2.003 mmol g−1). H2−TPR was carried out to investigate the reducibility of the RuCl3 species on the MgxAl−LDHs support. As shown in Fig. 4d, all RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs samples show obvious reduction peaks below 400 °C, indicating the RuCl3 species can be completely reduced at 400 °C. Besides, the main H2 consumption peaks shift to lower temperature with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio. It is reported that the surface basic sites can facilitate the reduction of RuOx species. For example, the reduction temperature of RuOx species decreased from 185 to 134 °C after the introduction of nitrogen into the mesoporous carbon support due to the enhanced surface basicity induced strong metal-support interaction [17]. We believe the lower reduction temperature of RuCl3/MgxAl−LDHs with the increased Mg/Al ratio was also caused by the increased content of surface basic sites, which is consistent with the CO2−TPD results. The electronic structures and chemical states of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Ru 3p 2/3 XPS spectra of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re was deconvoluted into three peaks centered at 465.7, 463.5 and 462.1 eV, which correspond to RuO2∙H2O (denoted as “Ruγ”), Ru4+ (denoted as “Ruβ”) and Ru0 (denoted as “Ruα”), respectively ( Fig. 5a). Compared with the normal Ru0, the binding energies of Ru0 of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re samples in this work show a clearly negative shift, with a largest value of 0.6 eV for Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re. The fraction of Ru0 first increase then decrease with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio from 1 to 4, with a maximum value of 47.6 % for Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re (Table S6), indicating that an enhanced metal Ru nanoparticle and MgAl-LDH support interactions was achieved with Mg/Al ratio = 3 via electronic transfer. The O 1 s XPS spectrum of Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re in Fig. 5b show the peaks around the binding energies of 532.4, 531.3 and 530.3 eV are attributed to the physically adsorbed surface hydroxyl via a noncovalent interaction (denoted as “Oγ”), defective oxygen species with low-coordination (denoted as “Oβ”) and lattice oxygen species in brucite-like layers of an edge-sharing M(OH)6 octahedron (denoted as “Oα”), respectively [40]. Interestingly, the Ru/Mg3Al−LDHs−Re sample process the largest amount of defective oxygen species (Table S7). The oxygen vacancies seem play an important role in the APR of methanol over Ru/MgxAl−LDH−Re catalysts. When the support MgxAl−LDH−Re was replaced by γ-Al2O3 without oxygen vacancies, low hydrogen production rate of was detected (Table S4, entry 9), which maybe also due to the oxygen vacancies introduced into the MgxAl−LDH−Re can serve as sites for methanol activation. PL spectra is well established as an effective tool to detect the surface defects, then PL spectra technique was employed to clarify the existence of oxygen vacancies (Fig. 5c). The PL spectra measurement was conducted at an excitation wavelength of 320 nm. The emission peak appeared at approximately 376 nm, which was due to the recombination of carries on the surface defects like oxygen vacancies. It is interesting to note that the increased Mg/Al molar ratio resulted in a pronounced fluorescence quenching, demonstrating a higher concentration of surface oxygen vacancies with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio. The oxygen vacancies were further confirmed by EPR. The EPR signals at the g value of 2.003 were clearly observed for all four Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re samples, which is due to the single electron O2− radical trapped by oxygen vacancies. The Ru/Mg4Al−LDHs−Re catalyst with the largest Mg/Al molar ratio exhibited a most intense signal compared with other samples (Fig. 5d), suggesting an increased amount of oxygen vacancies with the increase of Mg/Al molar ratio, which is in accordance with the O 1 s XPS and PL spectra results. The existence of oxygen vacancies on the surface of MgxAl−LDHs facilitated the reduction of RuCl3 species, which is in accordance with the data from H2-TPR results in Fig. 4d. For plasmon induced charge-carrier driven reactions, it is well established that the high energetic “hot electrons” were first generated via light excitation, then the “hot electrons” were injected into the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of reactants to activate the chemical bonds [41–44]. The electrons exchange between metal NPs and reactants lead the formation of the excited states of reactants in the timescale of femtoseconds. Thus, the plasmonic nature of Ru NPs under light irradiation was further investigated. Light adsorption ability is critical for plasmonic metal nanoparticles photocatalysts. The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra show that Ru/MgxAl−LDHs−Re samples exhibiting much stronger light absorption than that of MgxAl−LDHs supports in the light wavelength range of 300−800 nm (Fig. 5d), indicating that the loading of Ru nanoparticles enhanced the light utilization. An important factor to effectively driven the plasmon-enhanced photocatalytic reaction is that the energy level of photoexcited “hot electrons” need to be compatible to match the energy level of the LUMOs of reactants. Thus, regulation the energy level (carrier density) of photoexcited electrons play an important role to improve the photocatalytic efficiency of LSPR metal NPs photocatalysts. To figure out the effect of light irradiation on the adsorption and formation of intermediate species, in situ DRIFTS of the APR of methanol was performed. As shown in Fig. 6a, the time dependent evolution of intermediates over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re catalyst were first investigate in the dark at 150 °C. The infrared absorption characteristic peaks of the C–H bond stretching vibrations of methanol at 2975 and 2825 cm−1 appeared after the introduction of methanol and water into the in situ chamber. The infrared absorption characteristic peaks located at 2942 and 2865 cm−1 assigned C–H stretching vibrations of methoxy species (CH3O). Besides, the characteristic peaks at 1059 and 1018 cm−1 were also observed, which stand for the C–O vibrational of methoxy in monodentate and bidentate configurations, respectively. The characteristic peak at 1708 cm−1 is assigned to the adsorbed form aldehyde species. The characteristic peaks at 1517 and 1350 cm−1 assigned to νs(OCO) and νas(OCO) of the formate species (HCOO). All above observations indicating that the dissociative adsorption of methanol to methoxy happened at the initial stage of methanol APR reaction, followed by the transformation from methoxy to formaldehyde on the surface of Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re catalyst. The characteristic peak of CO was first observed at reaction time of 21 min, suggesting the deposition of formate to CO occurred. Then characteristic peak of CO2 also appeared at 21 min, suggesting the occurrence of WGS reaction. The reaction intermediates of methanol APR reaction under light irradiation are identical to that in the dark, as shown in Fig. 6b. However, the intensity of methoxy species (CH3O) was much lower compared with that in the dark at the same reaction time, suggesting that light irradiation promoted the dehydrogenation of methoxy to formaldehyde. Besides, a stronger intensity of CO was also observed under light irradiation at the same reaction time, suggesting the decomposition of formaldehyde was also greatly enhanced with the help of light irradiation. To further investigate the effect of oxygen vacancies on the activated dissociation of H2O, in situ DRIFTS of WGS was further conducted using oxygen vacancies enriched Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re and oxygen vacancies deficient Ru/Al2O3 to track the formation of intermediate species and the reaction mechanism in WGS. As shown in Fig. 6c, the characteristic peaks at 2300−2400 cm−1 belong to gaseous CO2 appeared over Ru/Al2O3 in the first minute, indicating the occurrence of WGS. Meanwhile, characteristic peaks ascribed to formates species at 1637, 1526, and 1393 cm−1 also occurred, and their intensity gradually increased with prolonged reaction time. Meanwhile, the intensities of gaseous CO2 also increased with prolonged reaction time, indicating that the formate species decompose to CO2 and H2, which is consistent with in situ DRIFTS results of the APR of methanol. Interestingly, for the in situ DRIFTS of WGS over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re catalyst in Fig. 6d, the characteristic peaks at 1520 cm−1 ascribed to carboxylate species and 1439 cm−1 ascribed to polydentate carbonate species can be observed, while none characteristic peaks signal of formate species are shown. It is worth to note that the signal of CO was very weak, which may be due to the quick conversion of CO via WGS reaction over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re. This suggests that the WGS reaction proceeded much more efficient over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re than Ru/Al2O3. The quite distinct intermediate detected over Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re suggests the WGS proceeded via two different mechanisms. The Ru/Al2O3 catalyst proceeded the formate pathway, namely the adsorbed CO on Ru nanoparticles reacted with surface hydroxyl group, followed by the decomposition of the formate species to H2 and CO2. Whereas the redox mechanism occurs over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re, water dissociation to H2 and adsorbed oxygen species on the oxygen vacancies, followed by the oxidation of CO by the oxygen species to produce CO2 over Ru/Mg3Al−LDH−Re. 3.4 DFT calculations DFT calculations on the reaction pathway were carried out by using the tetrahedral structure of Ru4 as the model, which is the smallest stable-cluster unit with three-dimensional spatial structure. As shown in Fig. 7, the Ru4 clusters were loaded on the single Mg3Al−LDH (00 l) surface via bonding with surface lattice oxygen (Ru−O), and the residual surface lattice oxygen were saturated by adsorbed hydrogens to construct the perfect adsorption model (Ru4/per-LDHs). The vacuum distance between the duplicate layers was set to 20 Å to avoid possible interactions between the supercells. One surface lattice oxygen of Ru4/per-LDHs was removed to build the oxygen vacancy model (Ru4/ov-LDHs). Further Bader charge calculations were carried out in order to understand the effect of oxygen vacancy on the electron transfer between Ru4 cluster and LDH. As show in Fig. 8a, about 0.61 electrons are transferred from LDH to Ru4 cluster in Ru4/ov-LDH, while in Ru4/per-LDH, only 0.05 electrons are transferred. Meanwhile, the adsorption energy of Ru4 clusters on different support was −6.61 eV (Ru4/ov-LDH) and −5.22 eV (Ru4/per-LDH), respectively, indicating that Ru4 cluster adsorbed more strongly to the ov-LDH substrate. The transfer of electrons from LDH to Ru may optimize the d-band center. Therefor the partial density of states (PDOS) of Ru 4d states on different substrates was further calculated. As shown in Fig. 8b, the d-band centers for Ru4/ov-LDH and Ru4/per-LDH are −0.90 eV and −1.51 eV, respectively, indicating that Ru4/ov-LDH is more active compared with Ru4/per-LDH. The effective energy barrier is defined as the energy difference between the most stable state and the highest transition state in a series of elementary reactions. As shown in Fig. 9a, the energy barriers for methanol dissociation to CH3O* and CH2O* on the Ru4/per-LDH surface are 0.424 eV and 0.755 eV, respectively, while the energy barriers for further dissociation increase substantially to 1.123 eV and 1.496 eV. However, the energy barriers for the dissociation of methanol into CH3O* and CH2O* were not only reduced on the Ru4/ov-LDH surface (to 0.232 eV and 0.448 eV, respectively) but also to 1.117 eV and 1.344 eV for TS3 and TS4, respectively. The effective energy barrier is defined as the energy difference between the most stable state and the highest transition state in a series of elementary reactions. The effective energy barrier for methanol dissociation on Ru4/ov-LDH (1.45 eV) is lower than that on Ru4/per-LDH (2.62 eV), indicating that methanol decomposition on Ru4/ov-LDH are more favorable than on Ru4/per-LDH, and may promote the reaction to produce more CO. Similarly, in the water-gas reaction, as shown in Fig. 9b, the energy barrier for the dissociation of water on the Ru4/ov-LDH surface as well as for the reaction of the next two steps is significantly reduced to 0.261, 1.470 and 1.742 eV, while the reaction energy barriers on the Ru4/per-LDH surface are 0.520, 2.268 and 2.093 eV, respectively. And the effective energy barrier on Ru4/ov-LDH is 2.21 eV, which is significantly lower than that on Ru4/per-LDH (4.24 eV), and is more favorable for hydrogen generation. 3.5 Mechanism of the APR of methanol Based on above detailed characterizations and in situ DRIFTS of methanol APR and WGS results, we proposed the possible mechanism and illustrated in Fig. 10. Initially, methanol was adsorbed and dissociated to form methoxyl species on the Ru nanoparticles (step 1), then the accumulated methoxyl species were further dehydrogenated to formaldehyde and form H2 and absorbed CO on the Ru sites (step 2–4). These results were demonstrated by time dependent in situ DRIFTS of APR of methanol. Afterwards, WGS reaction occurs via a redox mechanism, in which the oxygen atom of H2O was supposed to absorbed at the oxygen vacancies of MgAl−LDH (PL, XPS and EPR measurements were employed to prove the existence the oxygen vacancies), H atoms were released as molecular hydrogen, and the left oxygen species at the oxygen vacancies react with the absorbed CO to form CO2 and the oxygen vacancies were regenerated (step 5–9) for the next catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully prepared oxygen vacancy enriched MgAl−LDH supported Ru nanoparticles photocatalyst, which exhibited excellent catalytic activity for the APR of methanol under light irradiation at low temperature. Detailed characterizations showed that the catalytic performance of the dehydrogenation of methanol and its intermediates was significantly enhanced by the LSPR effect of Ru nanoparticles under light irradiation. Besides, the oxygen vacancies enriched MgAl−LDH support provided abundant crucial active sites for the activation of H2O, which resulted a faster redox mechanism in the WGS reaction. The synergistic effects of plasmonic Ru nanoparticles and the oxygen vacancies on the MgAl−LDH support contributed to the excellent catalytic performance of Ru/MgAl−LDH−Re. This work gives a deep understanding of the mechanism in the APR of methanol and offers a great promise for the rational design of highly efficient catalysts for methanol APR reaction. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic aqueous phase reforming of methanol is a promising process for the sustainable hydrogen production. The search for highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst is a topic of interest. Herein, we report oxygen vacancies enriched MgAl−LDHs supported plasmonic Ru nanoparticles catalyst exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance for efficient hydrogen production at 150 ºC under light irradiation. Characterizations demonstrate abundant oxygen vacancies are introduced into MgAl−LDHs via “memory effect”. The local electron transfer from oxygen vacancies of the MgAl−LDHs to the Ru nanoparticles leading the formation of electron-rich Ru species, which promote the dehydrogenation of methanol under light irradiation. In situ DRIFTS demonstrated a redox mechanism of water-gas shift reaction due to the existence of oxygen vacancies, which resulted a faster hydrogen production rate. This work displays a facile strategy for synthesis of oxygen vacancies rich LDH supported metal nanoparticles catalysts and deep understanding into the pathway and mechanism toward the effective hydrogen production.
